review_title: Systemic Discrimination: if non-Canadian, look elsewhere
pros: Good work life balance. Fair work load. Hybrid Remote Work Available. Extended health benefits are good, but other colleges have better unions, hence better benefits.
cons: Systemic discrimination by imposing high qualifications and work experience for entry-level positions. Employees are not valued for their efforts, there is no support for internal growth. The company prefers to hire externally them provide opportunities for internal employees to advance their careers in the Institute, which leads to high turnover, especially in entry-level positions. They leave BCIT for others companies/colleges that give them better career opportunities. Plus, if you are an immigrant or have English as Second Language you won’t reach any management-level position. BCIT claims to be an inclusive place, but only for entry-level positions. In upper-level positions, there are very few to none non-native English speakers. Pay is on the low side compared to private industries and a strong union environment makes it harder to actually achieve any pay increases.

pros: Good benefits, nice co-workers, high-tech

review_title: You should be interested in teaching.
pros: You have flexibility. During Summer, you are not assigned any teaching. You can spend your time for professional development, conducting research, working on projects with students, etc. Full-time regular faculty have 43 days of annual paid leave.
cons: The salary is much lower for PhD holders compared with industry. The teaching load is much heavier than research universities; however, internal research funds are available and you can apply for teaching release time to do research.

pros:
From day one, I've felt supported every step of the way through my career path. I've experienced an endless array of support for personal and professional development, an open door policy with leadership, and have found a team (Marketing & Communications) that tends to embrace connection with one another which makes this a positive space that excites me to come to work every day.

A fairly gracious, and comprehensive and useful benefits package is provided along with access to a vast array of health and wellness products to support me both personally and professionally.

Our departments leadership has an open door policy with leadership, and it's been my experience that management has warmly received any feedback, concerns, or ideas that I've brought to their attention. I very much appreciate this type of corporate culture.
cons: Working in post-secondary can be extremely different from private industry, and at first glance it may seem that salary grades can seem much lower than private corporations. This is more a tip to consider - remember to think about the total compensation package, it can be a lot more rewarding then you think.

So if you want to actually connect 1-1, grade student work, modify course material, for me that has always meant that I work about double the hours I actually get paid for.

review_title: Avoid this place if your can
pros:
Benefits package is decent with good coverage. Pay is good if you’re at a director level or higher. 
Job security during a pandemic is a bonus.
cons:
The management positions on the marketing team are held by people who cannot lead effectively. They have very little experience working or managing marketing teams outside of BCIT which leads to low efficiency on the team, poor decision making, and very little open mindedness for new ideas. Processes and task management is non existent and those in charge have no idea how to ensure that their employees workloads are manageable. 

There are too many meetings or spontaneous calls each week to “prioritize.” This comes from the lack of confidence that management has in their employees. Allow your employees to make decisions to get projects done in an efficient manner and let them learn from their mistakes. The back and forth with management to get approvals takes forever, even on the smallest of things. 

Specifically on the marketing team there is an issue with high turnover. This is very concerning for all employees on the team, but management I continues to believe that “employee turnover is a part of growth and should be welcomed.” Barely anyone stays on this team for longer than a year. Management chooses to turn a blind eye to the systemic issues and brush issues under the rug that leads to low employee morale and turnover. 

No opportunity to advance in your team as outside hires are favoured over internal people. 

HR at BCIT are not involved and are very disconnected from most employees. Often times emails with questions or concerns would go unanswered which is frustrating when asking about legitimate issues.

job_title: Senior IT Analyst in Burnaby, BC

cons: Union environment; many staff perform at minimum levels

review_title: Sadly BCIT is very typical of a government run organization
pros:
Benefits are good but even some of them are starting to get eroded away as the FSA gives back to management ... a little bit more every contract.  
   The students are great and a refreshing breath of fresh air as they still haven't been knocked down by the realities of life.
   The Gym is great and is free for staff and students.
cons:
The pay is generally too low. Lots of years with 0% - 1% pay increases as the Cost of Living seems to average 3% or more per year.
   Very poorly managed
   Lots and lots and lots of bureaucracy that prevents one from doing a good job efficiently ...  very typical of most government run organizations.
   BCIT used to hire Instructors who had good industry experience to pass on their 'hands-on' skills ... today they're being hired with little experience. That's likely because the pay, compared to industry, is low.
   Employee engagement doesn't really exist. Upper management... wherever they are ( and they've hired a lot of Directors and Managers over the past few years) ... are out-of-touch.
Low employee morale
Very bad and expensive overall cafeteria experience

pros: Great institution with a strong emphasis on personal development opportunities. From my experience, BCIT sets itself apart from other employers that offer personal development opportunities because supervisors and managers actually encourage you to build capacity in your day so that you can attend workshops/courses. They are also very supportive in that they too make these learning opportunities a priority and lead by example when such opportunities become available. There also seems to be a deep appetite for change. Like with most large organizations, change can be slow; however, the drive and desire to refine existing processes is evident in the work that is done. Overall, the work environment is great, the people are pleasant, it's a very reputable institution to work with, and the work can be fulfilling if you allow it to be.
cons: Being able to adapt to change is key but the challenge in larger organizations is that there are still groups who may be opposed to it. More specifically, if that change requires individuals to modify their current working styles/habits. In a perfect world, process improvements happen instantly; however, BCIT is a cluster of multiple unions and different working groups that come into play so it can often take longer to accelerate. With that said, some individuals/groups all carry the traditional "them vs us" mindset that benefits no one when it's perpetuated. There are a lot of great minds at the institution and everyone will benefit greatly working in harmony with one another.

pros: 35 hour work week with no weekend or holiday work, great benefits, free gym, free tuition, management makes an effort to be inclusive
cons: Lower than average pay among unions for same admin work, unions can hinder rather than help interactions with management, low amount of healthy food choices (but improving), food is expensive, more variety of science courses needed, initiative from high performing employees not recognized (everyone in Union must be treated the same which kills any incentive or reward for high results employees), culture across departments is too siloed so projects that require and involve coordination of many departments are often bogged down in turf wars, employee development is sorely lacking and needed badly, rarely do support staff move into management as BCIT seems to always hire externally for managers and fails to train current staff who want to and can do it, unequal unions and disparities cause friction among some staff

review_title: Love my job, but frustrated by barriers to improving the organization.
pros:
* gym membership
* excellent / flexible work hours, good vacation time
* good pension plan
* friendly community
* free courses for staff if you aren't displacing a paying student
cons:
* complex union environment, along with all the disadvantages that brings ("superhero" model, where some staff do the heavy lifting, while others coast)
* management is at the mercy of the unions, labour relations department is not effective
* inadequate training budget (which is one of the few rewards management can provide to the effective staff in lieu of a bonus)
* poor approach to strategic planning (plan published a year late, after the budget submissions were due)
* resistance to improving business processes

job_title: Instrument and Process Control in Vancouver, BC
pros: good facility, good instructors, good time
cons: covid ruined some aspects of learning

pros: very professional and hard working company
cons: a bit demanding at times

review_title: FSA Union allows for good work/life balance
job_title: Intermediate Systems Analyst, IT in Burnaby, BC
pros: Being part of the BCIT FSA Union is a huge perk for being an IT employee.  Full-time employees get 25 vacation days to start, 25 personal development days (take courses, go to conferences etc), 18 sick days (which role over to the next year) and the ability to be on a nine-day-fort-night schedule/flex schedule meaning that every two weeks you get a day off for working 48 more minutes a day (regular day is only 7 hour day, so a 7 hour 48 minute day isn't so bad). Free courses at BCIT. $1500 personal development fund a year, plus super personal development pool which allows for things such as conferences, accommodation and food. Nobody works a minute over their scheduled day, allowing for a great work/life balance.
cons: Lower pay than industry for technical roles. Older, aging team members. The median age is 50 years old for an IT department, which is crazy when you think about most innovating development teams. Being in your 30s is like being an infant in this department. Management won't do anything radicle because of the union environment, so people can coast on doing minimal work and not get fired. That being said, it takes FOREVER for anything to get done.

review_title: BCIT. Where careers go to die.
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Burnaby, BC
pros: Very good work-life balance and good benefits with the exception of paramedical ($10 a visit for podiatrist, chiropractor, physio, etc). Very generous vacation, sick leave and training/education time off. Decent pay for technical staff for Vancouver, though Vancouver has pretty bad tech pay in general and is a very expensive city in which to live. Relaxed environment, casual dress code, easy pace (which is a double-edged sword here). Also, a pretty respectful workplace.
cons: As I said, the easy pace has a downside too. Things take forever to get done and mediocrity is very acceptable. Engagement is very low, at least on the technical staff side. I can't speak for instructors. Career opportunities are virtually non-existent, no incentive via promotions, raises or even opportunities to really challenge yourself. Many of my co-workers lament how working here actually harms your career long-term. Senior management is quite myopic and risk-averse. Performance management is non-existent in my area, though I expect that has more to do with direct management than the institute.

pros:
- On-site gym, good amenities
- Lots of talented, experienced people in both teaching and administrative functions
- Very transit/bike commuter friendly (altho most employees seem to drive anyhow)
- Enrolment in pension plan
- A company you can slowly build a 35 year career at - this doesn't really exist anymore.
cons:
- Pay in most departments and employee groups, including management (!!) lag significantly behind market
- With current leadership, the job security and work/life balance which is supposed to justify a lower salary has been eroded
- Terrible top-down leadership, honestly or critical feedback quietly discouraged in favour of a "Yes" culture.
- Low-performers coddled or avoided altogether leading to inconsistent service levels and experience for students and colleagues

pros: Job security - being in an union, you cannot really get fired
cons:
Deteriorating work environment - budget constraints & lack of alternative revenue sources means more work for the same pay 

Major systemic issues - I worked in industry for many years, and I am not a big union guy for the simple reason that if you cannot get fired, there is little incentive for people to improve

On the other hand, the managers at BCIT, while there is the occasional bright star, generally lack the intuition, skills, and/or incentive to deal with people issue

When you add this all up, it is an unsustainable model at BCIT now - trying to hire industry 'experts' with low pay, coupled with a deteriorating work environment ... the Great Degeneration is on

pros:
The IT staff at the Downtown campus is very relaxed and easygoing. They make it easy to learn and offer support when needed. Otherwise, they let you solve problems yourself.
Because student shifts run 5pm to 9pm Monday to Friday, or 8:30am to 4:30pm on weekends, there is a lot of time where students have little to do. Staff allowed us to study for our classes as long as we paid attention to our email and left the service shutter open so people can ask us for help if needed. 

Really a great environment for a student looking to learn.
cons: The pay per hour is great (for students), but the amount of hours is low. If you need to pay all your bills of this, it will be tough.

review_title: Great reputation but room for improvements
pros: Polytechnic school that prepares students to be job ready. The faculty deliver quality programs, a lot of professional development available to staff through PD Funds or part-time studies fee waivers. Benefits are employer paid are good with the exception of paramedical services, excellent defined benefit pensions and vacation time off, New Year’s Eve & Christmas Eve are paid stats, highly subsidized employee parking and free onsite gym facilities at the Burnaby campus.
cons: Some employees have sense of entitlement, very low employee engagement throughout the institute, little to no management rights, better paramedical benefits needed - massage, physio, chiro, technology and work processes are out of date, flexible work arrangements and better salaries needed to attract people to BCIT and  lack of work life balance should be addressed in some departments.

review_title: BCIT School of Health Sciences was a terrible place to work
pros: Nice pension package,  competitive salary for management positions, and great gym free to employees.
cons:
Toxic environment filled with passive aggressive behavior. Senior management does not welcome new ideas, employees new to BCIT are expected to stick to the status quo no matter how outdated or ineffective it may be. 

My experience with HR at BCIT was a nightmare. They went above and beyond during my interview process but were never willing to help after I accepted the position. I tried to meet with my HR representative after I witnessed instances of bullying and inappropriate comments from a male about a female colleague. My request to meet was denied and instead HR informed my supervisor of my concerns who later reprimanded me as being disruptive to the culture of BCIT.

There is a high turnover rate with senior management and HR. Deans and Directors are fired or quit. The goals of one manger could be completely opposite of their replacement so setting long term goals is challenging.

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Burnaby, BC
pros: Great work/life balance, excellent benefits and vacation, lots of different areas of interest.
cons: Huge gulf between management and staff. No leadership training whatsoever for non-management. No support for cross-team development. Low morale and "engagement". HR bends over backwards for management, but doesn't work terribly hard supporting staff. Pay scales have fallen way behind similar jobs in the industry.

pros: The name.  Appears to be a steady employer.
cons: I know a number of ex-employees that are exited the same way.  After couple of years of employment, they will trump up some ridiculous reasons to push you out.  For me was "misconduct".  I had jury duty one day, and I told my chief-instructor's assistant I will be away for the day.  As it turns out the information was never passed on, the Associate Dean decided it was my misconduct.  Created an elaborate scheme to push me out.  BCIT is a "union" with its own bogus governing body and judicial process.  The HR was involved and a number of "witnesses" were involved.  After 3 years of employment they made a case.  Ironically, I knew the exact same thing that happened to an number of other ex-employees.  This is how they keep their "budget" always hiring the cheapest labour rate.

pros: Instructional training and support, competitive hourly rate, great support from the non-management, doesn't interfere with actual classroom time
cons: Only pays for hours teaching and not prep nor marking, if working part time, no reimbursement for parking

pros: some flexibility in how you do your job; good gym; some good benefits;
cons:
poor working conditions, generally. Mice/rats, old infrastructure, poorly maintained, and 
due to Political pressures management has an ax at everyone's throat threatening their jobs; very poor employee "engagement" (new progressive buzzword around BCIT);  Very slow to make good and meaningful changes ... government bureaucracy in slow motion. and,
low pay ... many years of 0% pay increases.   Education is now business first with little consideration to what's best for the students of BC.

review_title: Comfortable Job, Interesting Variety of Projects
pros: Great work-life balance. A nice variety of projects come through for employees in the Technology Center. Co-workers are interesting people and you also meet many clients. Unionized so they benefits such as vacation are pretty good.
cons: Lower pay than in industry.  Not a lot of money available for professional development outside of what is offered at the school itself. Unionized, so if there's a strike you are out of pay.

pros: Working with students is rewarding,  although challenging at times. Some of the management, staff and instructors are deeply committed.
cons: Management plays lip service  to be student-centred. In reality, there is an abundance of empire building, and self-serving decisions that are tolerated and even encouraged. Unfortunately, what management says, and what they do are often polar opposites. This is from my experience, in the School of  Business. With a new Dean, hopefully things will improve, but it will be a long and difficult journey.

pros:
- free tuition for BCIT courses for staff
- supports work-life balance 
- free gym membership, access to health programs, training & development
- generally good work colleagues
cons:
- union mentality of some staff hinders growth, progress, innovation, and can create a sense of entitlement 
- can be a frustrating workplace for highly driven, performance-oriented employees. 
- Set salary brackets, so do not get any additional compensation for high performance or delivery of outcomes.  
- pay is lower than working in private sector, which may attract less qualified employees

review_title: What you see is what you get
job_title: Facilities Coordinator in North Vancouver, BC
pros: Rated as one of the top 100 companies to work for in BC.  Consistent and stable, with little to no over lurking management eye on every little thing you do. Free to make changes to your work environment as you please with in the prescribed guidelines of your position. Able to move from different positions while still keeping your old position, in case you don't like the new one you are in. Good benefits for sick employees and their families, good benefits for new parents. Participate in courses offered for free as long as they are inline with your current position.
cons: BCIT is a top down management hierarchical  structure. I've worked here for 8 years and have had 3 (6) sets of managers. No fluid career platform that allows you to increase you income quickly. Very slow turn overs of new positions, old generation culture whom don't move up or out, people tend to stay in their positions for 10 or more years, making it difficult to move up. Heavily regulated by outside industries, making it difficult to find newly qualified individuals. As a unionized environment people tend to take advantage of their benefits and personal productivity seems to reduce year by year. As an established older generation of business, the employees are slow to change and adapt to new technologies available. You can only take new courses that are inline with your position and so it is very difficult to branch out to different industries. Little training is offered for new employees about their specific positions, most people find that the first 2 years are, learn as you go, making many mistakes as they become familiar with their duties.

pros: Well known and respected brand within BC. Better hours than working in an agency.
cons: Managers don't have any experience managing or in marketing positions outside of BCIT. Very high turnover in the marketing department. Most of my co-workers only stayed for less than 2 years and then left for greener pastures. The office is located at the very end of campus and far from any services (coffee!!)

job_title: Senior Unionized Professional Staff in Burnaby, BC
pros: Rock-solid pension, great vacation allowances, decent extended health benefits, 35-hour work week allows for good work-life balance.
cons: Bureaucratic, slow-moving, change-resistant, highly political, and below-average salaries: some of the reasons to avoid working at BCIT. There is little incentive to innovate or perform - advancement opportunities are minimal to non-existent; salaries are capped; performance isn't rewarded or punished. There's an overall sense of futility: the only changes are negative. Senior management is solely concerned with keeping their jobs or advancing their own career agenda.

pros: Relaxed work environment, good hours, good benefits, good opportunities for personal development
cons: Not unexpected for an educational institution, BCIT is very bureaucratic and static. There's little overall excitement nor incentive to excel; it's easy to look around and see colleagues young and old who are simply managing their days to retirement.

review_title: Very satisfied working on contract with BCIT
job_title: Contract Business Instructor in Vancouver, BC
pros:
Flexible, lots of programs available to teach once you get on staff as a contract instructor. 
Full benefits after teaching 250 hrs in one year, then 150 hrs per year to continue your benefits.
BCIT has a great reputation in the industry.
cons: Can be difficult to get substitute instructors if have a conflict with other work.

review_title: Worst Management and 'Leadership' of Anywhere I've Worked
pros:
Are becoming less...
There are some amazing Faculty and Staff - who have a passion to educate and a willingness to share what they know.
Lots of Vacation.
cons:
Excessive layers of middle managers, new Directorships created all the time, which never communicate downward.  
Zero Leadership - No VP has ever come to my department and met with us and asked for our feedback.  Same with the President, she is only seen at events.
There needs to be more insight into how money is spent - again, at the middle-management level, they seem to use funds at their personal discretion, for their pet projects, rather than asking professional staff/Faculty for input.
Change only comes when someone retires or is fired.

pros:
* Good Benefits/Pension
* Job Security
* Education fund (limited for support staff and managers, best for faculty)
* Free Gym membership  and various excersize classes
cons:
* Very little encouragement or reward for good service or extra effort
* Hirearchal environment with cultural spread and divisions between groups
* Hard to move up 
* Policies and size of institution make change very slow

review_title: Overall, its a supportive environment but doesn't compensate fairly for our expertise
pros: Lots of varied work with stakeholders that are passionate about what they do. Fair benefits and flexible work schedule. union support is great.
cons: Lack of resources across the institute means heavy workload for a non-profit and one that pays below industry average salaries.

review_title: Convenient place with some workplace politics
pros:
I work part time with the flexibility of it, but it is also less stable.
There are very many great departments at the institution.
Development stipend is provided if you work full time. 
As a public institution BCIT has good perks and benefits.
cons:
Big institution with all the cons. Slow, everybody is trying to glue themselves to the chair to save their jobs.
BCIT not hires instructors to reduce the expenses though they perform the same duties as other people currently working as full time regular faculty.

review_title: Some good benefits and flex time, but poor relations with management
pros: Flexible working hours. Some benefits are good. Good co-workers. Union protects workers from arrogant management.
cons:
HR department is terrible. Arrogant and worse than useless. They serve no useful purpose and job selection committees do all the work, including filtering of several dozen resumes. 
Poor working relationship with unions. Recent strike settled nothing and only worsened relationship. No collective agreement in over 4 years.

review_title: IT Services - Solid department to work for
job_title: Student Technology Assistant in Burnaby, BC
pros: The people within the department are nice to work with, and it's a great place to get started as a student taking a system administration program that needs the real-world experience.
cons: The helpdesk is a somewhat low-growth position, as the range of duties tend to be quite constrained, especially as a student employee. I don't know if I can recommend a long-term career on the helpdesk, though branching into one of the more specialized teams certainly seems appealing.

pros: Great community of people, our team is grand, I stay healthy by playing soccer at lunch and the benefits and pay are decent in my mind!
cons: At this moment I cannot think of a single one worth mentioning!

pros: Great place to work, good work-life balance, standard workload, free gym pass, free courses, good benefits, free workshops for employees, parking.
cons: Unionized environment can create some challenges and limitations for compensating fairly high-performing employees.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Vancouver, BC
pros: I love teaching at BCIT. I worked at another post-secondary institution before BCIT, and the level of support at BCIT for their PTS teachers is exceptional. I have complete autonomy in directing my course and curriculum, and have access to the tools that I need at the downtown campus. I would recommend it to anyone who has the opportunity to fill a similar role.
cons: Marketing resources to promote our own courses would be valuable.

review_title: Really nice team and a good place to work
pros: Vacation entitlement, nice workers, campus is beautiful, good salaries and regular performance reviews, lots of office space
cons: Scope of roles are limited, people with good experience and education end up being stuck doing administrative work, and collaboration was limited

pros: Rewarding experience working with students, feeling accomplished and glad to share my vast experience.
cons: Lot's of work preparing your own materials and marking up homework. Hourly rate does not sufficiently cover preparation time needed to do a good job. Sometimes disorganized administration forgets sending you vital info, you need to stay on top of it.

pros: Unionized environment and benefits, vacation days, flex days, sick days.
cons: It's all about who you know, not about how good you are at doing your job. Even though they have hiring committees, the management can veto employee's vote and hire the most incompetent person simply because they live on the same block.

review_title: British Columbia Museum of Technology !! Horrible Place to Work!!
job_title: Learning Technology Specialist in Burnaby, BC
pros: Can't think of anything positive except maybe some free training classes if your interested in taking a class that's not popular because they won't pay for it if the class is full
cons:
- Horrible management... Especially in the LTS.. Learning and Teaching Center
- weird dynamic with two separate Unions... And one is much better than the other.... 
- only 6 sick days per year or 18 if your in the better union... Wtf?
- beware... The LTS will hire you for one job and then 3 months later train you as a phone tech support person wether you like it or not!  
- most of the employees within the LTS have a long history of being unhappy and many have deep rooted resentments 
- management is afraid to do anything due to fear of people filing grievances with the unions
- some senior employees / instructional design consultants (mostly) and  a few others in the better union will constantly be going on vacation while you are left slaving away and faced with unrealistic deadlines
- they have no sense of project management 
- they do not care at all about their employees or their employees talents and strengths,
- they don't listen to any suggestions from employees
- lots of gossip going on all day
- lots of employees getting paid a lot and doing very little while others are slaving away doing all the grunt work
- incompetent management
- technology here is severely outdated and there is no budget for anything except for your bosses iPad and Mac Pro laptop
- there are people leading entire departments here with zero experience in that area
- run away from this depressing place!
- HR will not help you.... They are there for management only... Don't trust them
- unions are stressful to work with and filing a complaint with them will put a target on your back
- this is the most rigid, inflexible place I have ever worked.... It's shocking how inflexible they are!

pros: Reputable post-secondary education institution. Good job satisfaction helping student success. Opportunities for professional development especially if you are a faculty member.  Not so much for support staff.
cons: People tend to be territorial and unwilling to collaborate. Changes usually move slowly as its a large organization.  Need more communication from mid-management to staff.

pros: Decent benefits package, and my coworkers (apart from senior management) have been nice enough to work with.
cons: So much bureaucracy! Only way to advance is to have your boss quit! Way many decisions being made by "marketing" people who have no idea what's actually going on. Wages have been basically stagnant for us union folks for way too long. Lots of talk about "Engagement" without actually addressing any of the route causes.

job_title: Product Compliance Specialist in Burnaby, BC
pros: Very good working environment and friendly colleague. Give you enough freedom in your work.
cons: Low salary. Since the funds raised for research and development of the institute is limited, there is no salary for intern.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Burnaby, BC
pros: Love the students - great to work with
cons: Hate the Management -- incompetent and/or self-serving.

job_title: Student Technology Assistant in Burnaby, BC
pros: Picked up valuable experience in a larger organization, met great people, and learned a lot.
cons: Felt disconnected during the school year, sometimes feel like work done wasn't trusted, sometimes there wasn't as much communication as I'd like

pros: good benefits. and vacation time.
cons: do not treat instructors with respect, discriminate against visible minorities.Not an equal opportunity employer

pros: High profile, if you are interested in post-secondary environment, this is an employer of choice...not many other post-secondary environments do everything that BCIT does
cons: Very demanding, you are only as good as what you did yesterday. Poor Union and Management relations, high turnover

pros: Sharing your the knowledge and skills of your profession with a new generation
cons: Salaries are too low, workload too high

pros: location, easy_interview_process, training, infrastructure, facilities, training
cons: no supportive managers, no discipline in students, No TA to teaching faculties

review_title: Good support staff but horrible management
pros: Good benefits from working at the post-secondary institute
cons: Very isolated from the rest of the school and the management pretty much are over paid and are holding little credibility to the employees

pros: Good pension. Good vacation.  Students and Instructors are fantastic!!
cons: Complete management/leadership shambles.  No leadership. No presence.  Lots of politicking.  No respect for academic credentials, professional staff.   And they get paid a bundle!

pros: There is a lot of work especially around course start dates. The staff i.e. instructors and support staff are very friendly except for one or two which can be ignored.
cons: If there is an instructor who does not "like" you, he will lie and make up stories and the associate dean believes him instead of checking it out.

pros: Freedom in the classroom as long as there isn't a complaint.
cons: Reviews are non existent from employer and those from students are unimportant as they are meaningless in the big picture.  The push for more foreign bodies has put a real strain on maintaining any degree of quality in the curriculum.

pros: Great place to work, colleagues are very friendly and helpful. Opportunity to enroll in part-time courses.
cons: Some instructors do not provide enough support and guidance for the labs of the courses they teach.

pros: Flexibility, at the beginning of the year you can request upwards of 1 shift a week to as many as they need.
cons: You can walk away from a shift feeling rewarded but exhausted. A little more pay would be nice.

pros: Is a government run institution, so you get all the benefits of public sector employment.
cons: Depending on which building you working in, cell phone coverage can be difficult to receive, especially first level SE12

pros: Union work environment work environment
cons: FSA is weak and doesn't advocate well for part-time instructors, despite them being the backbone of BCIT's success.

review_title: Review about the Peer Tutor position I had
pros: I had flexible work hours
cons: Sometimes there would be too many students to help and not enough of us

review_title: Fun and good for making international connection within the campus.
job_title: Student Activity Guide in Vancouver, BC
pros: You get to make lots of international / multicultural connections within the campus.
cons: All the activity guides were let go without any explanation...which was very odd.

job_title: Business Development Coordinator in Burnaby, BC
pros:
- Nice people to work with
- Environment is also nice
- Stable job
cons:
- Salaries, if compared to other educational institutions, is below average
- Not many opportunities to grow within the company

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Burnaby, BC
pros: Good work:life balance. Decent benefit package.
cons: Poor employee engagement.  Few  options for career growth.

pros: interesting and a hands-on teachining and work environment.
cons: Fewer research outputs and not many graduate programs

job_title: Adjunct Professor, SOB in Burnaby, BC
pros: Gernerally a good community culture.
cons: Management is not responsive to teaching staff.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Burnaby, BC
pros: Well organization institution with a friendly working environment and fair paid salary
cons: I can not find any cons while I was working there

pros: 1. Flexibility, 2. Recreation and Support Services, 3. Professional Development
cons: 1. Leadership, 2. Bureaucracy, 3. Integration

pros: Everybody is very helpful and there is a real sense of community.
cons: The hourly rate is very low for tutors compare to the industry.

job_title: Tool Room Attendant in Burnaby, BC
pros: Producing skilled workers for our province n country
cons: The 7 hour daytime job in some department

review_title: Apply if you can- Good exp
pros: Fixable hours. You can meet a lot of new friends.
cons: Lower than tutoring others on an individual bases

pros: Good pay and benefits, plus they look out for their employees
cons: Parking can be a challenge at the Burnbaby campus

pros: great team great options great work
cons: growth oppurtunities, limited, managment could be better

pros: Supportive team, fantastic benefits, great work life balance.
cons: None yet, though I've only been there a short time.

pros: The employees were treated fairly. I enjoyed a lot.
cons: i didn't find any downside of my work

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Vancouver, BC
pros:
Friendly people
Great benefits
Unionized
Possibility of Growth
cons: I have nothing to complain about

pros: Generally a good place to work
cons: Run not as an educational institution, more as a department of the government.

pros: Good variety or work in and out of town
cons: Some issues getting direct information

job_title: Student Technology Assistant in Burnaby, BC
pros: People you work with are great and a fun work environment
cons: Sometimes communication between departments is not there

pros:
Review materials you learned. 
Connect with juniors.
cons: Not so many hours, around 4 ~ 8 hours a week.

pros: Good working environment and nice staff

pros: unionized, some decent learning opportunities, good connections
cons: none of the union benefits, must pay union dues, strict supervisors.

review_title: It was a great place to gain experience
pros: Laid back culture. Friendly people
cons: Unionized work force led to strikes

pros: It's a great to work at.
cons: the hours are limited and pay is low.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in North Vancouver, BC
pros: Working environment, training support, colleagues
cons: The lighted sign that needs to get fixed

pros: good place to work for sure
cons: nothing negtive, good experience for sure

pros: Strong unions, flexible schedules, generous time off, good people
cons: lower pay compare to most universities

pros: Great place to work and/or study at
cons: There are no Cons for BCIT

pros: Great training process, and support from all other employees
cons: Can't think of any cons...

pros: time off, well paid, professional development
cons: hard to make more money

pros: Flexible, nice people, great benefits
cons: Cyclical in nature, hard to get things done

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Burnaby, BC
pros: Very good benefit and vacation
cons: Not many restaurants around the area.

pros: Great instructors and great opportunities
cons: Heavy workload can lead to burnout

pros: Great benefits package and holidays
